title: لَوْلَا وَلَوْمَا
description: Learn about لولا and لوما, particles meaning 'if not for' or 'were it not for', used to express that something prevented an action from occurring.

notes.title: What are لولا and لوما?
content: لولا and لوما are particles meaning 'if not for' or 'were it not for'. They indicate that something (the مبتدأ) prevented the action in the response from happening.
They are called حرف امتناع لوجود: the result was absent because of the presence of something. لَوْلَا الْمَطَرُ لَذَهَبْتُ (Were it not for the rain, I would have gone).
keyPoints: لولا/لوما: 'if not for', 'were it not for'
Result didn't happen because of something's presence
Followed by a noun in nominative (مبتدأ)
The خبر is obligatorily deleted (محذوف وجوبًا)

examples.english: Were it not for the rain, I would have gone
Were it not for Allah, we would have perished
Were it not for knowledge, people would be lost
Were it not for you, I wouldn't have succeeded

notes.title: Structure of لولا Sentences
content: After لولا comes a noun (اسم) in the nominative case. This noun is the مبتدأ, and its خبر is understood to be 'موجود' (present/existing) but is always omitted.
The response (جواب) typically uses a past tense verb, often preceded by لَ: لَوْلَا زَيْدٌ لَأَكْرَمْتُكَ.
keyPoints: جواب لولا: usually past tense with لَ

examples.english: Were it not for hope, the heart would die
Were it not for your help, I would have failed
Were it not for the sun, there would be no life
Were it not for water, agriculture would perish

notes.title: لولا with Pronouns
content: When لولا is followed by a pronoun, it takes the separate (منفصل) form, not attached: لَوْلَا أَنْتَ (not لَوْلَاكَ in classical grammar, though لولاك is used in modern Arabic).
Examples: لَوْلَا أَنَا، لَوْلَا أَنْتَ، لَوْلَا هُوَ.
keyPoints: لَوْلَا أَنْتَ لَهَلَكْتُ (Were it not for you, I would have perished)
Modern usage allows attached: لَوْلَاكَ، لَوْلَاهُ

examples.english: Were it not for you, I wouldn't have known the way
Were it not for him, we would have gone astray
Were it not for me, the work wouldn't have been completed
Were it not for you, I would be in trouble (modern)

notes.title: لولا for Reproach (التحضيض)
content: لولا can also be used for التحضيض (urging/reproaching), meaning 'why don't you?' or 'you should have'. In this usage, it's followed by a verb, not a noun.
لَوْلَا تَسْتَغْفِرُونَ اللهَ (Why don't you seek forgiveness from Allah?). This is different from the conditional usage.
keyPoints: لولا + فعل مضارع = why don't you? (urging)
لولا + فعل ماضي = you should have (reproach)
Not conditional - expresses urging or blame
Common in Quran: لَوْلَا جَاءُوا عَلَيْهِ بِأَرْبَعَةِ شُهَدَاءَ

examples.english: Why don't you seek Allah's forgiveness?
You should have come to me yesterday
Why don't you speak the truth!

exercises.promptEn: Were it not for the _____, I would have gone
Were it not for Allah, we would have _____
_____ your help, I would have failed
Were it not for _____, I wouldn't have known the way

exercises.answer: were it not for / if not for
